episodes.natural_language:
Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif. The matter centers on two motor vehicle accidents and the medical treatment tied to them.

In an email thread dated February 6, 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm asked Sarena Tuttle to clarify which accident Muhammad Alif treated for at Starlite, querying whether the facility was Stalite, Modern, or Tri-State Injury. He stated that he believed the first accident involved a traumatic brain injury (TBI) only, while the second involved a neck and back injury.

Sarena Tuttle replied later that same day, explaining that all of Muhammad Alif’s providers are documented and that records and bills have been requested and are awaiting receipt. Providers have a minimum of 30 days to produce these documents. She noted that policy limits and PIP information cannot be released to Starlite prior to submitting a demand, which cannot be submitted until all medical bills and records are received. She added that Aaron typically waits to review medical bills before releasing PIP payments so he can determine how the available benefits should be allocated among multiple providers, especially since over $30,000 had already been incurred between two of them. She indicated she had forwarded this information to him for review, along with the statement that a civil suit was being “following” or “filed” on Muhammad Alif’s behalf, and that he would reach out to discuss the matter further.

Earlier that day, Nona Bacote had sent a separate message seeking clarification of Muhammad Alif’s medical treatment related to the two accidents. She stated that, on November 8, 2023, Muhammad Alif was involved in his first accident and received treatment at Parkridge Medical Center, followed by care from Norton Health Care, Cutting Edge, Anointed Hands, Mark Lynn, and Kort Physical Therapy, in that order. All imaging had been performed at Innovative Open MRI & Imaging Diagnostic Imaging Center in Lake Mary, Florida, and he had a consultation with Aptiv. She noted that on Wednesday, February 8, 2023, he would be going to Mayo Clinic in Rochester, New York for additional treatment. Farmers Insurance was identified as the insurance company for this accident, and all bills were to be sent to them for payment from the listed treatment centers. She requested policy limits from Farmers immediately.

Bacote also stated that, on December 9, 2023, Muhammad Alif was involved in his second accident in New York, where his cab was rear-ended by another vehicle. He had been seen only by Cutting Edge and Starlite Chiropractor for medical treatment for this incident, and he had uninsured motorist insurance in relation to this claim. She acknowledged that the information was extensive and asked to be advised if it was too much to handle.

The email thread closes with Aaron Whaley’s signature from Whaley Law Firm.

but requested I get clarification of which PIP you want to release and to
whom. We can release either the PIP from the 11/08 accident, the PIP from

Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email regarding Claim Review for PIP Release. The message was addressed to Nona Bacote, Tristateinjuryandrehab@gmail.com, and Muhammad Alif, with Aaron Whaley CC’d.

Sarena explained that she had discussed the claims with Aaron, and he is okay with releasing PIP but requires clarification on which PIP to release and to whom. The firm can release either the PIP from the 11/08 accident, the PIP from the 12/09 accident, or both. She asked for specific instructions about which providers should receive the funds. If releasing PIP to a provider that served both accidents, such as Cutting Edge, she asked for further specification of which billing should be paid.

She noted that two providers are seeking payment: Starlite Chiro and Cutting Edge Medical Services. Gail advised that the billing for Starlite Chiro is over $10,000.00, though Gail is awaiting toner to print a billing statement for the client. For Cutting Edge Medical Services, she referenced an attached document. Between these two providers, they are currently claiming over $30,000.00 in medicals to date date. She also cautioned that there will possibly be outstanding medical bills to address at the negotiation or settlement of the claims.

The email closes with the expectation of receiving directions from the client. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, and the office line is (502) 583-4022 ext 104. She can be reached at Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

The message notes the patient Muhammad Alif (DOB: April 16, 1961) with a date of injury of November 8, 2022 and a current balance of $21,874.75. It states that Muhammad Alif completed a telehealth visit with Christ. The following plan was recommended: 1) await MRI brain imaging to be performed, and receive reports/imaging; 2) review all symptomatology and answer any questions pertaining to care; 3) complete the ordered TBI testing; 4) pursue an evaluation with Dr. Hwang for a neurologist evaluation, pending; 5) follow up in one week via telemedicine. The sender requested contacting the patient to schedule the one-week follow-up appointment.

Best regards,

Administration
Cutting Edge Orthopedic Services
Carrollton | Houston | San Antonio | El Paso
Phone: (972) 978-2525

The information contained in this transmission may contain privileged and confidential information, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws. It is intended only for the use of the person(s) named above. If you are not the intended recipient, any review, dissemination, distribution, or duplication of this communication is strictly prohibited and we ask that you please contact the sender via email: admin@ceostx.com or telephone (975) 978-2525 and destroy all copies of the original message.

On November 8, 2022, in the Muhammad-Alif-MVA case, the client Muhammad Alif contacted us regarding a motor vehicle accident. He called back four times while he was away for lunch, and I received a fifth call from him while I was on the phone with FG. I returned his call.

He again asked us to find out Policy Limits, and I again explained that we cannot force disclosure of Policy Limits. We spent another twenty minutes on the phone. #cc

In the Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022 file, the matter involves Muhammad Alif and a request for a PIP release. The communication thread begins with an email sent on January 31, 2023 at 10:50 AM from Starisha Curry, Director of Operations at Anointed Hands Injury & Rehab (anointedhandsinjuryrehab@gmail.com). In that message, she asked, “Good morning!! Can we get a PIP release on Muhammad Alif?” The email was addressed to Justin Chumbley at the Whaley Law Firm (Ph: 502-583-4022; Fax: 502-364-9363).

The thread continued on February 9, 2023. At 11:04 AM, Starisha Curry sent another message requesting a PIP release on Muhammad Alif, this time to Justin Chumbley and to Aaron Whaley (agwhaley@louisville-accident-lawyer.com; agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com), with the subject line “Re: PIP Release.” Shortly thereafter, at 11:07 AM on the same day, a reply appeared from Justin Chumbley of the Whaley Law Firm, as indicated by the header information listing his contact details (Ph: 502-583-4022; Fax: 502-364-9363).

Later on February 9, 2023 at 11:15:03 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent a message to Starisha Curry. In this email, she requested that The Whaley Law Firm receive Muhammad Alif’s current records and bills, and she provided her contact details, including her new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with The Whaley Law Firm’s mailing address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and phone numbers (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104). The message is marked with the subject line “Re: FW: PIP Release” and includes the associated correspondence from the prior exchanges.

The exchange clearly shows an ongoing effort to obtain a PIP release for Muhammad Alif, with initial outreach on January 31, 2023, follow-up inquiries on February 9, 2023, and a subsequent request for current records and bills communicated by Sarena Tuttle later that day. The email thread centers on the PIP release matter, with subject lines referencing “PIP Release” and “FW: PIP Release,” and includes contact details for all parties involved.

Client: Muhammad Alif

In a correspondence thread regarding a claim review for PIP release, the matter began with an email dated February 7, 2023. Gail Sweasy, writing from tristateinjuryandrehab@gmail.com, informed Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm that Muhammad (“Mo”) wants PIP released to pay Anointed Hands for the first wreck and Starlite for the second wreck, and that PIP should not be released for Cutting Edge yet.

In a prior reply dated February 6, 2023, Sarena Tuttle advised Mo after discussing the matter with Aaron. He was okay with releasing PIP but needed clarification on which PIP to release and to whom. The options were to release the PIP from the 11/08 accident, the PIP from the 12/09 accident, or both. Sarena requested that Mo specify which providers should receive the released funds. If the release benefits a provider that supplied services for both accidents, such as Cutting Edge, Mo should further specify which billing to pay.

Sarena reminded Mo that two providers are seeking payment: Starlite Chiro and Cutting Edge Medical Services. Gail had advised that Starlite’s billing is over $10,000, though she is awaiting toner to print a billing statement. Cutting Edge Medical Services has stated billing of over $30,000 in medicals to date. It was also noted that there may be outstanding medical bills addressed during the negotiation or settlement of Mo’s claims. The message concluded with a request for directions and acknowledged that further communication would follow.

Signature details in the February 6 email included:

Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, KY sent an external email to Ashley Becerra of West Bend Mutual Insurance regarding the claim, with the subject line “Re: Claim: AP92071 | MUHAMMED ALIF.” In her message, Sarena thanked Ashley for providing the records and medical bills and advised that the case involves a commercial policy with commercial limits; based on the materials she had received so far, she understood West Bend to be unable to disclose the limits. She noted that she was still awaiting records from Kort Physical Therapy and Park Ridge and requested a copy of the insured’s Declaration Page or Coverage Confirmation listing the policy limits, in order to make a policy limit demand since Mr. Alif remains in treatment and will continue to incur additional billing. Sarena attached several documents to the email, including items dated February 6, 2023 and February 2, 2023: “Alif MB Cutting Edge Medical Service,” “Alif MB Legent Imaging - MVA 110822,” “Alif MR Cutting Edge Medical Service” (two separate attachments), and “Alif MR Dr. Chiufang Hwang - TBI Bat…” She provided her contact details as well: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Direct Line 502-357-9971; Office 502-583-4022 ext. 104; Email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com with a note indicating a new email address.

Ashley Becerra’s reply chain includes a response later on February 9, 2023 at 10:05 AM. In that message, Ashley acknowledged the claim involving Muhammed Alif and stated she was following up on the last email. She noted that the prior message indicated Mr. Alif was being treated with Kort Physical Therapy and by a neurologist, and she requested details to understand the diagnosis or rationale for neurologist involvement, what the treatment consists of, and specifically what the physical therapy treatment for the neck, back, shoulders, and knee entails. She also asked whether there is an established treatment plan.

Finally, on February 10, 2023 at 13:54:19 +0000, Ashley sent a follow-up email reiterating thanks for the records and medical bills. She informed Sarena that the policy in question is a commercial policy with commercial limits and that West Bend is unable to provide its limits at this time. She requested that Sarena keep West Bend updated with all medical bills and records.

Ashley Becerra’s signature block appears in both of her messages: she is a Senior Claims Representative in Casualty Claims for West Bend Specialty, with West Bend Mutual Insurance at 1900 South 18th Avenue, West Bend, WI 53095. Her contact numbers are Toll Free 800.760.9250 Ext 3631, direct line 608-410-3631, fax 877-434-9585, and email abecerra@wbmi.com.

__Muhammed Alif Brain Testing Approval__
From: Axon Medical Centers Admin [Admin@amctbi.com](mailto:Admin@amctbi.com)
To: MUHAMMED ALIF [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com), "Dr. Allen Starkey" [drallen@ceostx.com](mailto:drallen@ceostx.com)
CC: 
Date: Mon, 13 Feb 2023 06:45:06 -0800 (PST)

Hi ,
 We are requesting approval for TBI testing for MUHAMMED ALIF, who is a patient of Dr. William Hwang, MD, double board-certified in neurology and psychiatry, with a specialty in physical medicine, rehab, and sleep disorders. Dr. Hwang recommends the following procedures: Oculomotor assessment, Posturography, Neurocognitive testing, Brain Mapping, and MRI/DTI prior to treatment. These tests are performed to better identify traumatic brain injury. The TBI battery includes:Oculomotor assessment - $2,000Neurocognitive testing - $2,200Posturography this battery - $500Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology - $8,000The DTI/MRI - $8,000If you would like to learn more about how multifactorial testing is beneficial for identifying brain injuries please click the following link (http://meet.ceostx.com) to schedule a time to speak with Dr. Matt DeGaetano. If you are unable to find time or would like to speak with him directly please contact him at drmatt@ceostx.com Indications: Oculomotor assessment: brain injury, headaches, fatigue, blurry vision, foggy thinking, reading difficulties, cognitive challenges, balance issues, trouble sleeping, and mood changes blurred vision, double vision, nausea, dizziness, balance problems, unsteadiness, falls, vertigo, spinning sensation, lightheadedness Posturography: brain injury, dizziness, balance problems, unsteadiness, falls, vertigo, spinning sensation, lightheadedness Neurocognitive testing: can help determine the areas of the brain that are impacted by a TBI and how these impairments are impacting your day-to-day functioning. More importantly, testing can also determine how other factors (e.g. depression, anxiety, life stress) are impacting your cognitive functioning, memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, anxiety, post-traumatic stress. Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology: the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art, real-time imaging/brain training available. Visualize live activity in the Limbic system, anterior cingulate, fusiform gyrus, Brodmann areas, and more by recording 19 channels of brain activity simultaneously. Brain dysfunction can have a variety of causes (encephalopathy), memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, cognitive decline. DTI/MRI: Diffusion tensor imaging is an MRI technique that uses anisotropic diffusion to estimate the axonal (white matter) organization of the brain. Fiber tractography (FT) is a 3D reconstruction technique to assess neural tracts using data collected by diffusion tensor imaging. A non-invasive medical imaging tool is used to investigate the structure of white matter that is damaged during a Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) without any neurological symptoms
 ---Administration Axon Medical CentersDallas | Houston | San Antonio | El Paso | AustinPhone: 855-296-6824The information contained in this transmission may contain privileged and confidential information, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws. It is intended only for the use of the person(s) named above. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any review, dissemination, distribution, or duplication of this communication is strictly prohibited and we ask that you please contact the sender via email: admin@amctbi.com or telephone 855-296-6824 and destroy all copies of the original message 
 Please reply back accepting or denying requests. Additionally, please attach a LOP if testing is approved!

Case Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022 concerns client Muhammad Alif. On February 13, 2023, Axon Medical Centers Admin, emailing from Admin@amctbi.com, sent a message with the subject “Muhammed Alif Brain Testing Approval” to MUHAMMED ALIF at sarena@whaleylawfirm.com and to “Dr. Allen Starkey” at drallen@ceostx.com. The date and time on the message are Mon, 13 Feb 2023 06:45:06 -0800 (PST). The email requests approval for traumatic brain injury (TBI) testing for MUHAMMED ALIF, who is a patient of Dr. William Hwang, MD, who is double board-certified in neurology and psychiatry and has a specialty in physical medicine, rehab, and sleep disorders. Dr. Hwang recommends the following procedures: oculomotor assessment, posturography, neurocognitive testing, brain mapping, and MRI/DTI prior to treatment. The TBI testing battery is itemized as follows: oculomotor assessment — $2,000; neurocognitive testing — $2,200; posturography — $500; brain mapping and electrophysiology — $8,000; and the DTI/MRI — $8,000. If you would like to learn more about how multifactorial testing is beneficial for identifying brain injuries, please click the link http://meet.ceostx.com to schedule a time to speak with Dr. Matt DeGaetano. If scheduling is difficult or you would like to speak with him directly, please contact drmatt@ceostx.com. Indications for the tests are as follows: for oculomotor assessment, brain injury, headaches, fatigue, blurry vision, foggy thinking, reading difficulties, cognitive challenges, balance issues, trouble sleeping, and mood changes; blurred vision, double vision, nausea, dizziness, balance problems, unsteadiness, falls, vertigo, spinning sensation, and lightheadedness are also listed. For posturography, indications include brain injury, dizziness, balance problems, unsteadiness, falls, vertigo, spinning sensation, and lightheadedness. For neurocognitive testing, the assessment can help determine the areas of the brain impacted by a TBI and how these impairments affect day-to-day functioning; importantly, testing can also determine how factors such as depression, anxiety, and life stress are impacting cognitive functioning, memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress. For Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology, the note describes it as the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art, real-time imaging/brain training available, enabling visualization of live activity in the limbic system, anterior cingulate, fusiform gyrus, Brodmann areas, and more by recording 19 channels of brain activity simultaneously; brain dysfunction can have various causes (encephalopathy), with symptoms including memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, and cognitive decline. For DTI/MRI, it explains that diffusion tensor imaging is an MRI technique using anisotropic diffusion to estimate the axonal (white matter) organization of the brain; fiber tractography (FT) is a 3D reconstruction technique to assess neural tracts using DTI data; this non-invasive imaging tool investigates the structure of white matter damaged during a TBI, even in the absence of neurological symptoms. 

Administration for Axon Medical Centers is listed as Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, El Paso, and Austin, with phone number 855-296-6824. The message also includes a standard privacy notice stating that the information in the transmission may contain privileged and confidential information, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws, and that it is intended only for the named recipient. If you are not the intended recipient, review, dissemination, distribution, or duplication is strictly prohibited, and you are asked to contact the sender at admin@amctbi.com or 855-296-6824 and destroy all copies. The email concludes with a request to reply back accepting or denying the requests, and to attach a LOP if testing is approved.

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif.

Initial client contact occurred on February 13, 2023, when Muhammad Alif emailed Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding a payment ledger from Farmers Insurance related to his motor vehicle accident dated November 8, 2022. In his message, he stated that he clearly understands who is being paid among the listed providers and asked whether the insurance company has been made aware of these bills. He also mentioned plans to see a speech pathologist and to send information about his neurologist and psychiatric treatment. Additionally, he noted that he has applied for health insurance and would have related information the next day. 

Earlier that same day, at 3:20 PM, Sarena replied to the thread explaining that the Payment Ledger is for his first accident and that what is listed reflects what the providers sent to Farmers. She provided her contact details and an updated email address, and she explained that the ledger had been attached along with a breakdown of payments. She listed the following: S&M Billing & Management – billed $6,090.00, paid $3,865.00; Innovation Open MRI – billed $3,200.00, paid $1,600.00; Lynn Family Vision & Training – billed $485.00, paid $485.00; Partners in Physical Therapy – billed $1,118.00, paid $838.00; Norton Leatherman Spine – billed $305.00, paid $305.00. In addition, ParkRidge East Hospital was billed $5,673.40; Radiology Alliance billed $458.00; Spring Creek Emergency Physicians billed $1,707.00; Modern Chiropractic billed $450.00; Mark Lynn & Associates billed $300.00; and Aptiva Health billed $1,475.00. The PIP Adjuster had applied $7,093.00 in payments as listed, leaving $14,168.40 in outstanding medical bills not including $25,213.45 for Cutting Edge, Lynn Family Vision, and the KORT Physical Therapy that had not yet been submitted to Farmers. She invited Muhammad to contact Aaron if he had questions about the information.

At 4:04 PM, Muhammad responded with thanks for the swift reply and sought clarification, asking whether all of these bills were for the first accident. He also noted that he would soon be released from chiropractic care, but he continued to experience head pain and memory loss related to the first accident and stressed the importance of following doctors’ orders regarding treatment for his traumatic brain injury (TBI).

At 4:08 PM, Sarena replied with a brief confirmation: the payment ledger is for his first accident and reflects what the providers sent to Farmers. Her message also included her updated contact information, including a new email address: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS). The thread captures the ongoing discussion around the ledger, the 1st-accident billing, and the steps forward in addressing the claims and treatment needs.

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif.

On February 13, 2023, at 3:20 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm emailed Muhammad Alif regarding his PIP Payment Ledger. She stated that the ledger had been received in the mail, was attached, and listed the payments made by the PIP carrier. She noted that a $1,000 deductible was applied to the S&M Billing & Management invoices and that this would be discussed further during the negotiation phase of the claim. She provided a provider-by-provider breakdown: S&M Billing & Management billed $6,090.00 and was paid $3,865.00; Innovation Open MRI billed $3,200.00 and was paid $1,600.00; Lynn Family Vision & Training billed $485.00 and was paid $485.00; Partners in Physical Therapy billed $1,118.00 and was paid $838.00; Norton Leatherman Spine billed $305.00 and was paid $305.00. Additional bills listed included ParkRidge East Hospital ($5,673.40), Radiology Alliance ($458.00), Spring Creek Emergency Physicians ($1,707.00), Modern Chiropractic ($450.00), Mark Lynn & Associates ($300.00), and Aptiva Health ($1,475.00). She also noted that the PIP Adjuster had applied $7,093.00 in payments as listed, and that Muhammad currently has $14,168.40 in outstanding medical bills not including the $25,213.45 for Cutting Edge, Lynn Family Vision, and the KORT Physical Therapy that have not been submitted to Farmers at this time. She invited Muhammad to contact Aaron to discuss any questions in further detail and included her contact information and new email address.

At 4:04 PM the same day, Muhammad Alif replied to Serena, asking for clarification on whether all of these bills are for his first accident. He also mentioned that he would be released from chiropractic care very soon, but he continued to experience significant head pain and memory loss related to the first accident. He emphasized the importance of following doctors’ orders for his traumatic brain injury (TBI) treatment and added that he would be seeing a speech pathologist and would send information about his neurologist’s psychiatric treatment. He also noted that he had applied for health insurance and would share that information the following day.

At 4:08 PM, Sarena responded to Muhammad, clarifying that the Payment Ledger is for his first accident and that what appeared on the ledger is exactly what the providers had sent to Farmers.

Later that same day, at 6:23 PM, Muhammad replied again, stating that he understood which providers were being paid and asked whether the insurance company had been notified about these bills. He also reiterated that he would be seeing a speech pathologist and would provide information about his neurologist’s psychiatric treatment. He again noted that he had applied for health insurance and would have that information tomorrow.

On February 14, 2023, at 11:00:12 AM (Eastern Time), Sarena M. Tuttle sent another update to Muhammad and the other recipients. She explained that the information came from Muhammad’s PIP carrier, and that his BI carrier was aware of some—but not all—of the bills at that time. As discussed, they would request records and bills from all providers to ensure both sides have copies of all records and invoices. She requested that Muhammad provide his speech pathologist’s name and address as soon as possible so they could obtain those records and bills, noting that this information should be available to him on Norton MyChart. She congratulated him on applying for medical health insurance and cautioned that treatment before the coverage date can be denied, but that this situation would be reviewed and discussed in more detail during the claim negotiation phase. She invited Muhammad to contact them with any questions. The message included The Whaley Law Firm’s address—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222—and direct lines: D (502) 357-9971, O (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to use the new email address. The message was sent to Muhammad Alif (stimulus110@yahoo.com), Aaron Whaley (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com), Nona Bacote (nibacote40@verizon.net), and Gail Sweasy (Tristateinjuryandrehab@gmail.com).

In the ongoing matter concerning the Payment Ledger from Farmers Insurance, Muhammad Alif corresponded with The Whaley Law Firm beginning on February 13, 2023. At 3:20 PM that day, Sarena M. Tuttle wrote that the PIP Payment Ledger had been received in the mail and attached to the email. She itemized the payments and bills, noting that the $1,000 deductible had been applied to the S&M Billing & Management invoices and would be discussed in further detail during the negotiation phase of the claim. The ledger showed: S&M Billing & Management billed $6,090.00 and paid $3,865.00; Innovation Open MRI billed $3,200.00 and paid $1,600.00; Lynn Family Vision & Training billed $485.00 and paid $485.00; Partners in Physical Therapy billed $1,118.00 and paid $838.00; Norton Leatherman Spine billed $305.00 and paid $305.00; ParkRidge East Hospital billed $5,673.40; Radiology Alliance billed $458.00; Spring Creek Emergency Physicians billed $1,707.00; Modern Chiropractic billed $450.00; Mark Lynn & Associates billed $300.00; and Aptiva Health billed $1,475.00. She also informed Muhammad that his PIP Adjuster had applied $7,093.00 in payments as listed, and that there were $14,168.40 in outstanding medical bills, not counting $25,213.45 for Cutting Edge, Lynn Family Vision, and the KORT Physical Therapy that had not yet been submitted to Farmers. If he had questions about the information or how the bills would be handled, she invited him to contact Aaron to discuss further.

Earlier that same day, at 4:04 PM, Muhammad Alif replied for clarification, asking whether all the listed bills were indeed for his first accident. He also mentioned that he would be released from chiropractic care very soon but continued to experience head pain and memory loss related to the first accident, emphasizing the importance of following his doctors’ orders for his traumatic brain injury (TBI) treatment. He added that he would be seeing a speech pathologist and would send information about his neurologist psych treatment, and that he had applied for health insurance with information to be provided the next day.

A short time later, at 4:08 PM on February 13, 2023, Sarena Tuttle responded: “The Payment Ledger is for your 1st accident & what is listed is what the providers have sent to Farmers.” This confirmed the scope of the ledger as pertaining to the first accident.

In the same thread, at 6:23 PM on February 13, 2023, Muhammad wrote again, confirming his understanding of who was being paid. He asked whether the insurance company on the side had been made aware of these bills and reiterated that he would be seeing a speech pathologist and would send information about his neurologist psych treatment. He also stated that he had applied for health insurance and would have that information the following day.

The following day, February 14, 2023, at 11:00 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied that the information in the ledger had been provided by Muhammad’s PIP carrier, and that his BI carrier was aware of some bills but not all at this time, with similar uncertainty regarding the PIP carrier. Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022
Client: Muhammad Alif

__Re: Filing a lawsuit__
From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Muhammad Alif [stimulus110@yahoo.com](mailto:stimulus110@yahoo.com), Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
CC: 
Date: Tue, 14 Feb 2023 13:57:56 -0500

I understand. I spoke to the adjuster and they are not disclosing limits
because in the adjuster's words "there is not a concern that this claim
will exceed the limits". She said it is a commercial policy and they have
sufficient limits. I assume they have at least $500,000, likely
$1,000,000. If you want to file a lawsuit we can. I will tell you what I
tell everyone. Lawsuits are not fast. If you are wanting speed then a
lawsuit is not fast. Lawsuits are, however, certain. That is what you get
with a suit. I don't usually like to file a lawsuit unless there is some
sort of impasse. Either there is a liability dispute or a dispute over
value that exceeds the cost of litigation. We are not to either of these.
There is some merit in filing suit now if we think one of these disputes is
inevitable. But, if we do and it turns out that they are on board with our
way of thinking that will not necessarily get us out of litigation. Defense
counsel will almost certainly want to be involved and complete discovery,
depositions etc.
So in short. Litigation is long and costly but we get to an eventual
resolution. Pre-litigation is shorter and cheaper but we may not resolve
the case and end up in litigation anyway.

I will leave it up to you with this information.

>
>
> Sent from Yahoo Mail for iPad 
>

-- 
Aaron Whaley
Whaley Law Firm

Louisville, KY 40222

episodes.natural_language:
This case, Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022, involves client Muhammad Alif and concerns an automobile/motor vehicle accident. In a message dated February 14, 2023 at 13:57:56 -0500, attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm responded to Muhammad Alif and to Sarena Tuttle regarding whether a lawsuit should be filed. Whaley explained that he had spoken with the adjuster, who was not disclosing policy limits because, in the adjuster’s words, “there is not a concern that this claim will exceed the limits.” The adjuster stated it is a commercial policy with sufficient limits, and Whaley assumed the insurer had at least $500,000, and likely $1,000,000. He offered to file a lawsuit if the client wished, but cautioned that lawsuits are not fast and, if pursued, are usually certain; they are not typically filed unless there is some impasse. Whaley noted there can be merit in filing if one of two disputes—liability or value enough to trigger litigation costs—appears inevitable. However, he did not consider the case to be at an impasse, stating that if a suit were filed, defense counsel would almost certainly engage and proceed with discovery, depositions, and related steps. In summary, he described litigation as long and costly but with eventual resolution, and pre-litigation as shorter and cheaper but with the risk of ending up in litigation anyway. He concluded by leaving the decision to the client based on this information.

Earlier that same day, at 9:38 AM, Muhammad Alif wrote to Counselor Whaley expressing significant concern about the automobile accident cases and requesting that a lawsuit be filed against Harbor House, described as the owner of the commercial vehicle in accident number one. He noted that it had been 90 days with no information on policy limits and indicated a belief that insurance companies like to “play games,” urging Whaley to push to file the lawsuit. The message was sent from Yahoo Mail for iPad. The note includes the signature block for Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022), indicating the communication style and contact details associated with the matter.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif.

On February 14, 2023, Muhammad Alif (stimulus110@yahoo.com) sent an email to counsel at Whaley Law Firm (Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle) with the subject “Re: Filing a lawsuit.” In the 9:38 AM message, he wrote from Yahoo Mail for iPad that he was very disturbed about the automobile accident cases and requested that the attorney file a lawsuit against harbor house, the owner of the commercial vehicle involved in accident number one. He stated it had been 90 days with no information on policy limits and asserted that insurance companies “like to play games,” asking the attorney to push the envelope to file a lawsuit.

That same day, at 1:58 PM, Aaron Whaley responded. He explained that he had spoken to the adjuster, who would not disclose policy limits because, in the adjuster’s words, “there is not a concern that this claim will exceed the limits.” He stated the policy is commercial and that they have sufficient limits, estimating at least $500,000, likely $1,000,000. Whaley advised that lawsuits can be pursued, but cautioned that they are not fast; if speed is the goal, a lawsuit is not the route. He noted that lawsuits are, however, certain and described his usual stance: he does not typically file a lawsuit unless there is some impasse—either a liability dispute or a dispute over value that exceeds the cost of litigation. He explained there might be merit in filing now if one of these disputes appears inevitable, but even if a suit is filed and the opposing side agrees with their approach, it does not guarantee avoidance of litigation. He warned that defense counsel would likely want to participate and conduct discovery and depositions. In summary, he said litigation is long and costly but can lead to an eventual resolution, while pre-litigation is shorter and cheaper but may still result in litigation. He concluded by saying he would leave the decision to the client based on this information.

Later that day, at 7:48 PM, Muhammad Alif replied: “Thank you, counselor for a speedy response. It’s no need for a lawsuit. I just had to have some information about the numbers.” This message was sent from Yahoo Mail for iPad.

The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information appears in the thread as follows: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

__Muhammad Alif Brain Testing Approval__
From: Axon Medical Centers Admin [Admin@amctbi.com](mailto:Admin@amctbi.com)
To: Muhammad Alif [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com), "Dr. Allen Starkey" [drallen@amctbi.com](mailto:drallen@amctbi.com)
CC: 
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 2023 12:38:58 -0800 (PST)

Hi,
 We are requesting approval for TBI testing for Muhammad Alif, who is a patient of Dr. William Hwang, MD, double board-certified in neurology and psychiatry, with a specialty in physical medicine, rehab, and sleep disorders. Dr. Hwang recommends the following procedures: Brain Mapping, and MRI/DTI prior to treatment. These tests are performed to better identify traumatic brain injury. The TBI battery includes:Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology - $8,000The DTI/MRI - $8,000If you would like to learn more about how multifactorial testing is beneficial for identifying brain injuries please click the following link (http://meet.ceostx.com) to schedule a time to speak with Dr. Matt DeGaetano. If you are unable to find time or would like to speak with him directly please contact him at drmatt@ceostx.com Indications: Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology: the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art, real-time imaging/brain training available. Visualize live activity in the Limbic system, anterior cingulate, fusiform gyrus, Brodmann areas, and more by recording 19 channels of brain activity simultaneously. Brain dysfunction can have a variety of causes (encephalopathy), memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, cognitive decline. DTI/MRI: Diffusion tensor imaging is an MRI technique that uses anisotropic diffusion to estimate the axonal (white matter) organization of the brain. Fiber tractography (FT) is a 3D reconstruction technique to assess neural tracts using data collected by diffusion tensor imaging. A non-invasive medical imaging tool is used to investigate the structure of white matter that is damaged during a Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) without any neurological symptoms
 Please reply back accepting or denying requests. Additionally, please attach a LOP if testing is approved! 
 ---Administration Axon Medical CentersDallas | Houston | San Antonio | El Paso | AustinPhone: 855-296-6824The information contained in this transmission may contain privileged and confidential information, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws. It is intended only for the use of the person(s) named above. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any review, dissemination, distribution, or duplication of this communication is strictly prohibited and we ask that you please contact the sender via email: admin@amctbi.com or telephone 855-296-6824 and destroy all copies of the original message

Case Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022 involves client Muhammad Alif. An internal email titled “Muhammad Alif Brain Testing Approval” was sent from Axon Medical Centers Admin (Admin@amctbi.com) on March 9, 2023 at 12:38:58 PM Pacific Standard Time. The message was addressed to Muhammad Alif at sarena@whaleylawfirm.com and to Dr. Allen Starkey at drallen@amctbi.com, with no listed recipients in CC.

In the body of the email, Axon Medical Centers requested approval for traumatic brain injury (TBI) testing for Muhammad Alif, who is a patient of Dr. William Hwang, MD, a physician double board-certified in neurology and psychiatry, with a specialty in physical medicine, rehabilitation, and sleep disorders. Dr. Hwang recommends Brain Mapping and MRI/DTI prior to treatment. The TBI battery comprises Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology at $8,000 and the DTI/MRI at $8,000. The email provides a link (http://meet.ceostx.com) to schedule a time with Dr. Matt DeGaetano if the recipient would like to learn more about how multifactorial testing can identify brain injuries. If scheduling time is difficult or a direct conversation is preferred, the contact for Dr. DeGaetano is drmatt@ceostx.com. 

Indications for Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology: described as the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art, real-time imaging/brain training available. The procedure visualizes live activity in the limbic system, anterior cingulate, fusiform gyrus, Brodmann areas, and more by recording 19 channels of brain activity simultaneously. Brain dysfunction can have a variety of causes (encephalopathy) and may manifest as memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, and cognitive decline. Indications for DTI/MRI explain that diffusion tensor imaging is an MRI technique that uses anisotropic diffusion to estimate the axonal (white matter) organization of the brain, and that fiber tractography (FT) is a 3D reconstruction technique to assess neural tracts using data from diffusion tensor imaging. It is a non-invasive medical imaging tool used to investigate the structure of white matter that is damaged during a Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) without any neurological symptoms.

The sender requests a reply indicating acceptance or denial of the testing, and asks that a Letter of Protection (LOP) be attached if testing is approved. The message closes with the administration contact details for Axon Medical Centers, serving Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, El Paso, and Austin, at 855-296-6824. A confidentiality note follows, indicating that the transmission may contain privileged and confidential information, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws, and instructing unintended recipients to contact the sender and destroy all copies.

Case Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022 involves client Muhammad Alif. In March 2023, the matter included a forwarded email thread titled “Fwd: Muhammad Alif Brain Testing Approval.” On March 14, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, forwarded this item to Aaron Whaley with the note “Another Request for Approval of Brain Mapping…,” and she included her firm contact details and a note to use her new email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

The forwarded thread contains a message from Axon Medical Centers Admin dated March 9, 2023, at 3:39 PM, with the subject “Muhammad Alif Brain Testing Approval.” The email is addressed to Muhammad Alif and to Dr. Allen Starkey (drallen@amctbi.com). It states that Axon Medical Centers are requesting approval for traumatic brain injury (TBI) testing for Muhammad Alif, who is a patient of Dr. William Hwang, MD, a physician who is double board-certified in neurology and psychiatry and whose specialty includes physical medicine, rehabilitation, and sleep disorders. Dr. Hwang recommends two procedures prior to treatment: Brain Mapping and MRI/DTI. These tests are intended to better identify traumatic brain injury.

The TBI testing package, or battery, includes Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology for $8,000 and DTI/MRI for $8,000. The message invites the recipient to learn more about multifactorial testing via the link http://meet.ceostx.com and provides Dr. Matt DeGaetano’s contact at drmatt@ceostx.com for direct discussion if scheduling is needed. The Indications section explains that Brain Mapping and Electrophysiology provide the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art, real-time imaging and brain training available, allowing visualization of live activity in the limbic system, anterior cingulate, fusiform gyrus, Brodmann areas, and more by recording 19 channels of brain activity simultaneously. It notes that brain dysfunction can have a variety of causes, including encephalopathy, memory loss, lack of concentration, brain fog, irritability, forgetfulness, and cognitive decline. For the DTI/MRI, the email describes diffusion tensor imaging as a technique that estimates the axonal (white matter) organization of the brain, with fiber tractography as a 3D reconstruction method to assess neural tracts using DTI data; it is a non-invasive imaging tool used to investigate white matter damaged during traumatic brain injury, even in the absence of neurological symptoms.

The message asks the recipient to reply with acceptance or denial and to attach a Letter of Protection (LOP) if testing is approved. The administration contact is Axon Medical Centers, which operates in Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, El Paso, and Austin, with a general phone number of 855-296-6824. The message also contains a standard confidentiality notice stating that the information in the transmission may be privileged and confidential, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws, and that it is intended only for the named recipients. If the recipient is not the intended person, review, dissemination, distribution, or duplication is prohibited, and the recipient should contact the sender at admin@amctbi.com or 855-296-6824 and destroy all copies of the original message.

The following plan was recommended: first, await a new lumbar spine MRI imaging, as the patient reports he is still experiencing considerable pain; second, review all symptomatology and answer any questions pertaining to care; third, instruct the patient to contact the clinic for any specific problems or issues; and fourth, schedule a follow-up in four weeks in the clinic. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit on March 17, 2023.

Best regards, Administration, Axon Medical Centers, serving Dallas, Houston, San Antonio, El Paso, and Austin. Phone: 855-296-6824. The transmission may contain privileged and confidential information, including patient information protected by federal and state privacy laws, and is intended only for the named recipients. If you are not the intended recipient, review, dissemination, distribution, or duplication of this communication is strictly prohibited. Please contact the sender at admin@amctbi.com or call 855-296-6824 and destroy all copies of the original message.

On June 20, 2023, Ashley Becerra, a Senior Claims Representative for Casualty Claims at West Bend Mutual Insurance, sent a message requesting the initial ER records for Mr. Alif and asking for a status update on whether Mr. Alif is still treating and, if so, how he is treating. The sender identified was Ashley Becerra and the message was part of an external inquiry regarding MUHAMMED ALIF, with the subject line “Re: Claim: AP92071 | MUHAMMED ALIF.” Becerra’s contact details include West Bend Mutual Insurance, 1900 South 18th Avenue, West Bend, WI 53095; toll-free 800.760.9250 ext. 3631; direct line 608-410-3631; fax 877-434-9585; email abecerra@wbmi.com.

Later on June 21, 2023, at approximately 10:54 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Ashley. In that message, she stated that the records were attached and that she believed Mr. Alif had completed treatment, but he would need to verify that with Aaron. Sarena provided her contact details as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line was (502) 357-9971, and the office line was (502) 583-4022 ext. 104. She also included her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com and noted that it was a new email address with a parenthetical reminder: “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

At about 11:20 AM on the same day, Sarena sent another email to Ashley, with Aaron Whaley CC’d, providing an update on the claim. She relayed that Aaron had confirmed Mr. Alif had completed treatment and that the demand was in the drafting process. She added that once the Demand was completed, it would be forwarded to Ashley as soon as possible, and she invited Ashley to contact them if there were any further questions.

Earlier that same day, there was a separate note from Sarena dated June 21, 2023 at 10:54 AM indicating that the records were attached and that she believed Mr. Alif had completed treatment but would need to verify that with Aaron; this message similarly included her signature with the new Whaley Law Firm email address.

Also on June 21, 2023, at 4:23 PM UTC, Ashley Becerra’s out-of-office reply was received, stating that she would be out of the office from July 1, 2023, to July 10, 2023. The auto-reply included her standard signature and contact information, reiterating her West Bend Mutual Insurance role and contact channels listed earlier (explicitly noting her absence dates). The out-of-office message also carried her West Bend contact details as previously provided: West Bend Mutual Insurance, 1900 South 18th Avenue, West Bend, WI 53095; Toll Free 800.760.9250 Ext 3631; Direct Ph: 608-410-3631; Fax: 877-434-9585; Email: abecerra@wbmi.com.

In summary, the communications between West Bend Mutual Insurance and The Whaley Law Firm during June 20–21, 2023, established that initial ER records were requested, attachments were sent indicating that Mr. Alif’s treatment appeared to be complete pending verification, and that Aaron Whaley had confirmed completion of treatment with the demand currently in the drafting process and to be forwarded once complete. The record also notes Ashley Becerra’s out-of-office period scheduled for July 1–July 10, 2023, with her contact details and new email address for the Whaley Law Firm correspondence.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif.

The record includes a sequence of email exchanges regarding a prescription approval for Muhammad Alif. In the chain, the earliest referenced message is from July 31, 2023, when the LOP Department informed The Whaley Law Firm that they had just received a high-cost prescription for the patient and that approval would be required before dispensing. They also stated that, due to the high cost, they could not accept any reductions for this medication and advised the recipient to see the attached materials. The message was sent from the LOP Department and included the sender’s contact details (Brenda Juarez, LOP Department Manager) and the ASP Cares corporate messaging, along with a standard STATEMENT OF CONFIDENTIALITY at the end—addressing 13988 Diplomat Dr., Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234, with P: 214-919-2534, Fax: 972-330-2783, D: 214-903-3373, and email addresses bjuarez@aspcares.com and lop@aspcares.com. The communication also instructed that ALL payments be sent to the Corporate Office at ASP Cares, 13988 Diplomat Dr., Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234.

On August 1, 2023, at approximately 1:07 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied. She is a Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager, located at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line was 502-357-9971, and the office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104. Her email was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting it as a new address). In her response, she thanked the sender and instructed that Mr. Alif’s private health insurance should be billed for the medication.

Later on August 1, 2023, at approximately 3:10 PM, Brenda Juarez, LOP Department Manager, sent a follow-up email to the same recipient. In this message, she stated that no medication had yet been filled for the patient and that they were still waiting on the LOP. The email reiterated the same ASP Cares contact information and the corporate payment instruction, including the address at 13988 Diplomat Dr., Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234, with P: 214-919-2534, Fax: 972-330-2783, and D: 214-903-3373, and the email addresses bjuarez@aspcares.com and lop@aspcares.com. It also included the standard STATEMENT OF CONFIDENTIALITY.

Across the chain, the messages consistently noted the confidentiality of the communications, each containing a STATEMENT OF CONFIDENTIALITY, and the correspondence documented the ongoing consideration of a high-cost prescription requiring formal approval before dispensing, along with the policy that no price reductions could be offered for this medication. The communications also documented the instruction to bill private health insurance for the medication and the administrative details for payments and contact information for both the LOP Department and The Whaley Law Firm.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. The client is Muhammad Alif. The records reflect a Prescription Approval Request Form for Muhammad Alif and show a sequence of email exchanges between The Whaley Law Firm and ASP Cares’ LOP Department regarding how to handle a high-cost prescription for this patient.

The thread begins with a July 31, 2023 email from the LOP Department at ASP Cares. They state that they have just received a high-cost prescription for the patient mentioned above and that approval is required before dispensing. They also note that due to the high cost, they cannot accept any reductions for this medication and ask the recipient to review the attached materials. The message includes the LOP contact information and a confidentiality disclaimer, and it urges that all payments be sent to ASP Cares’ corporate office at 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234.

On August 1, 2023, at approximately 1:07 PM, Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note the address of the email) responded. She wrote, “Thank you for reaching out. Please bill Mr. Alif’s private health insurance for this medication.” Her message also carried her standard signature block, which includes her contact information and the note to please use the new email address.

Later on August 1, 2023, at approximately 4:10 PM (the time shown as 4:10? PM in the record), the LOP Department replied. They stated that no medication had yet been filled for the patient and that they were still waiting on the LOP (the LOP). The reply also appeared with the usual confidentiality notice and the ASP Cares contact details (13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234; P: 214-919-2534; Fax: 972-330-2783; D: 214-903-3373; bjuarez@aspcares.com; lop@aspcares.com).

On August 2, 2023, at 09:56 AM, Sarena Tuttle wrote again: “Good morning, We have advised that you should bill the patients health insurance for these medications.” She signed her message with her Whaley Law Firm details and reiterated the new email address.

In summary, the case involves a high-cost prescription for Muhammad Alif that required prior approval before dispensing. There was an explicit push to bill the patient’s private health insurance for the medication, a clarification that no medications had yet been filled pending approval, and ongoing communications between The Whaley Law Firm and the LOP Department, with the corporate ASP Cares payment instructions and confidentiality language included in the signatures of the respective emails.

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. The client is Muhammad Alif. The notes describe a Prescription Approval Request Form for Muhammad Alif. On August 4, 2023, at 13:08:29 Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager with The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email regarding the Re: Prescription Approval Request Form for Muhammad Alif and attached the requested LOP Rx Approval Form. Her contact details are listed as The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (new email address noted). The message was addressed to the LOP Department at ASP Cares, and included a confidentiality note typical of such correspondence.

Earlier in the thread, on August 2, 2023, at approximately 11:18 AM (the record shows as 11:18?AM), the LOP Department replied: “We will have the medication transferred out to their local pharmacy. Thank you!” The signature block for Brenda Juarez, LOP Department Manager, follows, including the office address at 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234; telephone 214-919-2534; fax 972-330-2783; direct line 214-903-3373; email bjuarez@aspcares.com and lop@aspcares.com. The message also asks that all payments be sent to the ASP Cares corporate office at the same Diplomat Dr. address.

The same day, August 2, 2023, Sarena Tuttle included a confidentiality notice and wrote: “Good morning, We have advised that you should bill the patient’s health insurance for these medications.” Her signature again lists her role at The Whaley Law Firm and provides the same contact details as above, including the new email address.

Earlier still, on August 1, 2023, at 1:07 PM, Sarena Tuttle wrote: “Thank you for reaching out. Please bill Mr. Alif’s private health insurance for this medication.” Her message carried the same contact details and the note about the new email address.

On August 1, 2023, at 4:10 PM, the LOP Department responded: “We have not filled any medication for the patient yet. We are still waiting on the LOP.” This message also included Brenda Juarez’s signature and the same ASP Cares contact details, as well as the confidentiality notice.

On July 31, 2023, at 12:29 PM, the LOP Department had written: “Hello, We just received a high-cost prescription for the patient mentioned above to which we will need approval before dispensing. Also, due to the high cost, we cannot accept any reductions for this medication. Please see attached.” This message was signed by the LOP Department and included the corporate ASP Cares address and confidentiality notice.

Across these exchanges, the thread consistently shows the case file for Muhammad Alif, the handling of a high-cost prescription requiring prior approval, and the ongoing directive to bill the patient’s private health insurance rather than accepting reductions. The communications repeatedly feature the parties involved: Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm and Brenda Juarez, LOP Department Manager at ASP Cares, along with the corporate payments instruction and the standard confidentiality notices attached to email correspondence.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif. This matter concerns a high-cost prescription for Mr. Alif that required prior approval (LOP approval) before dispensing. The communications span late July to early August 2023 and involve the LOP Department at ASP Cares and The Whaley Law Firm on behalf of the patient.

On July 31, 2023, the LOP Department sent a message stating that they had just received a high-cost prescription for the patient mentioned above and would need approval before dispensing. They added that due to the high cost, they could not accept any reductions for this medication, and they requested the recipient to review the attached materials. The message was signed by Brenda Juarez, LOP Dept. Manager, and included the LOP department’s contact details (13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234; P: 214-919-2534; Fax: 972-330-2783; D: 214-903-3373; bjuarez@aspcares.com; lop@aspcares.com) along with a confidentiality notice stating that the contents are intended for the addressee and may be privileged; it also instructed that all payments be sent to the ASP Cares corporate office at the same Diplomat Drive address.

The following day, August 1, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied at 1:07 PM, thanking the sender and advising that Mr. Alif’s private health insurance should be billed for this medication. Sarena’s signature identified her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with addresses and contact details including 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the address as the new email). Earlier that same day, the LOP Department responded at 4:10 PM, noting that they had not filled any medication for the patient yet and were still waiting on the LOP.

On August 2, 2023, at 8:56 AM, Sarena again advised that the patient’s health insurance should be billed for these medications. Later that day, at 11:18 AM, the LOP Department wrote that they would have the medication transferred to the patient’s local pharmacy and thanked the recipient. Brenda Juarez’s signature block was included again, with the same contact information and payment instructions, followed by the confidentiality statement.

On August 4, 2023, at 12:08 PM, Sarena sent another message noting that the Requested LOP Rx Approval Form was attached, and she again provided her contact information and updated email address. Then, at 12:29 PM on the same day, Brenda Juarez replied with a brief “Thank you!” Her reply included the same signature block and the corporate office address for payments, reiterating that all payments should be sent to ASP Cares at 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234. The exchanges also contained the standard Statement of Confidentiality applicable to the emails, indicating that the contents were intended for the addressee(s) and may be privileged; recipients who were not the intended addressee were advised not to read or disclose the transmission and to delete it if received in error.

Throughout the thread, the messages referenced the intended process for approving and processing a high-cost prescription for Muhammad Alif, including billing to private health insurance or the patient’s health insurance, transferring the medication to a local pharmacy, awaiting the LOP approval, and sending payments to the corporate ASP Cares office. The correspondence also included standard contact details for both the LOP Department at ASP Cares and The Whaley Law Firm, as well as confidentiality notices embedded in each message.

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif.

In August 2023, a sequence of email communications concerned a high-cost prescription for Muhammad Alif, related to his motor vehicle accident (MVA) case. The correspondence involved Brenda Juarez, LOP Department Manager at ASP Cares, and Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm. The discussion centered on obtaining approval to dispense the medication and on billing arrangements.

The thread began on July 31, 2023, when the LOP Department noted that the patient’s prescription was high-cost and would require approval before dispensing. The note also stated that due to the high cost, they could not accept an unspecified option that was left incomplete in the original message. On August 1, 2023 at 1:07 PM, Sarena advised that Mr. Alif’s private health insurance should be billed for the medication. Later that same day, at 4:10 PM, the LOP Department replied that they had not yet filled any medication for the patient and were still waiting on the LOP.

The following day, August 2, 2023, at 8:56 AM, Sarena reiterated the recommendation to bill the patient’s private health insurance for the medications. Then at 11:18 AM, the LOP Department stated that they would have the medication transferred out to the patient’s local pharmacy. By August 4, 2023, the communications included a note from Sarena indicating that the requested LOP Rx Approval Form had been attached.

On August 4, 2023 at 12:08 PM, Sarena again confirmed the attached form was sent, and Brenda Juarez subsequently sent an additional message at 12:29 PM to acknowledge and sign off, with the standard confidentiality notice included in the email. Finally, at 3:12 PM (August 4, 2023, 15:12:56 -0500), Brenda clarified the cost details: the cost of the medication is $3,000.00 with no reduction, and she invited any questions at her phone number (214-903-3373). She noted that an updated approval form was attached and provided her contact information and the ASP Cares corporate office address for payments: ASP Cares, 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234. The communications repeatedly included the standard confidentiality statements typical of these emails, indicating that the contents were intended solely for the addressee(s) and were confidential and privileged if applicable.

In summary, the main facts are: the patient Muhammad Alif’s prescription was identified as high-cost and requiring prior approval; the recommended billing approach was to bill Mr. Alif’s private health insurance; the medication was to be transferred to the patient’s local pharmacy; the established payments were to be sent to ASP Cares’ corporate office; and the updated LOP Rx Approval Form was attached in the communications. The documented cost of the medication was $3,000.00 with no reductions, and Brenda Juarez provided the final confirmation and contact details related to the approval and payment process.

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022
Client: Muhammad Alif

In August 2023, the Whaley Law Firm’s file concerning Muhammad Alif, whose motor vehicle accident case is dated 11-08-2022, included a running email thread about a prescription approval for his medication. On August 7, 2023, Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note: this is a new email address), forwarded to Aaron Whaley an email titled “Prescription Approval Request Form - Muhammad Alif.” In that forwarded message, she wrote: “Apparently Mo's Medication is actually $3000.00 not $1000.00 - Need new approval form.” This included the context that the medication cost had changed and a new approval form was required.

Earlier in the thread, on August 4, 2023, Brenda Juarez, LOP Dept. Manager at ASP Cares (address: 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234; P: 214-919-2534; D: 214-903-3373; Fax: 972-330-2783; bjuarez@aspcares.com; lop@aspcares.com; corporate payments to: ASP Cares, 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234), responded to the matter. In a message dated August 4, 2023 at 4:13 PM, she stated that there had been confusion on their part and that the medication cost is $3,000.00 with no reduction. She invited any questions and provided her contact number (214-903-3373) and noted the updated approval form attached. She also included the ASP Cares office information and the confidentiality statement common to their emails. Earlier that same day, at 12:08 PM, Sarena Tuttle had written to Brenda: “Please find attached the Requested LOP Rx Approval Form.” Brenda later replied with a brief “Thank you!” at 12:29 PM.

The email chain began with Sarena Tuttle’s guidance on billing and prescription handling. On August 1, 2023 at 1:07 PM, Sarena wrote: “Thank you for reaching out. Please bill Mr. Alif's private health insurance for this medication.” Later that afternoon, at 4:10 PM, the LOP Department responded: “We have not filled any medication for the patient yet. We are still waiting on the LOP.” The following day, August 2, 2023 at 8:56 AM, Sarena stated: “Good morning, We have advised that you should bill the patients health insurance for these medications.” At 11:18 AM that day, the LOP Department replied: “We will have the medication transferred out to their local pharmacy.”

Thus, the thread shows a sequence of steps: initial instruction to bill private health insurance, acknowledgment that no medication had been filled yet while awaiting the LOP, the plan to transfer the medication to the local pharmacy, and finally the September/early August exchange preparing for an updated LOP Rx Approval Form reflecting the $3,000 cost.

Amid these exchanges, the correspondence consistently included standard confidentiality notices. The final note in the chain, dated August 7, 2023, is a forward of Sarena’s earlier message to Aaron Whaley with the line about the medication costing $3,000 and the need for a new approval form. The thread thus documents ongoing coordination between The Whaley Law Firm and ASP Cares regarding Muhammad Alif’s LOP medication, including cost updates, billing instructions to private health insurance, and the processing of the LOP Rx Approval Form.

- ASP Cares (LOP Department): 13988 Diplomat Dr. Suite 100, Farmers Branch, TX 75234; P: 214-919-2534; Fax: 972-330-2783; D: 214-903-3373; bjuarez@aspcares.com; lop@aspcares.com; and a directive to send all payments to the ASP Cares Corporate Office at the same address.
- Each email in the thread contained a standard STATEMENT OF CONFIDENTIALITY, indicating that the contents and attachments were intended for the addressee(s) and may be confidential or privileged, with instructions to delete or respond if received in error.

In brief, the thread documents: the initiation of prescription-related communication for Muhammad Alif, regulatory steps including LOP coordination and medication transfer to a local pharmacy, insurance billing guidance, the preparation and attachment of the LOP Rx Approval Form, collaboration on cost clarification ($3,000 with no reduction), and the final update confirming an updated prescription approval form.

She explained that the video is too large to send by email, so she had reached out to their IT department to transmit the information. Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. The client is Muhammad Alif, whose motor vehicle accident occurred on November 8, 2022. The file includes a chain of communications about his treatment plan, routed among his attorney, his medical evaluators, and the law firm handling his case.

On August 8, 2023, Muhammad Alif wrote to Dr. Robert Van Boven, beginning the message: “Good evening Dr. Robert Vanboven, I Muhammad Alif have been inform by my, attorney Aaron Whaley that my personal injury case relating to accident on November 8, 2022 has been low ball with a insulting offer of $13,000, myself and Council have talk over and over about my treatment plan, and my case status, I am requesting you Dr. Vanboven to take a meeting ,with my permission to discuss my treatment plan with Council, and determine the direction my case is going, I trust I have the right team in place to handle my business.” The message ends with “Sent from Yahoo Mail for iPhone,” and is signed by Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm at the bottom of the forwarded message.

The reply came on August 10, 2023: in a message from Dr. Robert Van Boven, M.D., D.D.S., Medical and Scientific Director and Board-certified Neurologist at Axon Medical Centers, he wrote: “Dear Mr. Alif: Having performed a neurological evaluation of your current status, I would be interested in sharing my pleliminary assessment of your disabilities and ongoing and future needs with your attorney. Mr. Whaley, please let me know days/times that work for you.” The email is addressed to Muhammad Alif with Aaron Whaley and Dr. Matt DeGaetano cc’d (drmatt@amctbi.com), and is dated August 10, 2023 at 6:59 PM (the timestamp shows a question mark in the original).

On August 28, 2023, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message titled “Treatment plan for Muhammad Alif” to Muhammad Alif, at the email address associated with Muhammad Alif MVA 11/08/2022 (the file path referenced as muhammadalifz2328962@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The forwarded header shows the chain originated with the August 10 message from Dr. Van Boven and was sent to Muhammad Alif with Aaron Whaley and Dr. Matt DeGaetano cc’d (drmatt@amctbi.com). The forwarded thread documents that the subject was “Re: Treatment plan for Muhammad Alif,” and the original correspondence included: the August 10 response from Dr. Van Boven sharing that he had conducted a neurological evaluation and his willingness to share his preliminary assessment with Alif’s attorney, and the request to Mr. Whaley to provide convenient days and times for a meeting.

In sum, the case file for Muhammad Alif, related to the November 8, 2022 motor vehicle accident, includes an August 8, 2023 client request to discuss treatment planning with Dr. Van Boven and counsel; an August 10, 2023 confirmation from Dr. Van Boven that he performed a neurological evaluation and that he would share his preliminary assessment with Alif’s attorney, pending scheduling input from Mr. Whaley; and an August 28, 2023 forwarding of the related “Treatment plan for Muhammad Alif” communication by Aaron Whaley, with the original contact chain including Muhammad Alif, Aaron Whaley, and Dr. Matt DeGaetano. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details appear in the signature: 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022
Client: Muhammad Alif

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd call from Client - Advised claim going in to litigation - He again asked about policy limits and whether the Def will have to disclose - Advised not right away - Limits may be disclosed during the Discovery Process - He also asked if he would be receiving copies of all correspondence through out litigation - Advised that it is not typical for us to cc Client on all correspondence - he is welcome to call in for updates as things progress but they do take time - He expressed understanding 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: August 28 2023
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on August 28, 2023 with Sarena regarding Muhammad Alif's motor vehicle accident case Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. I received a call from the client and advised that the claim is going into litigation. He asked again about policy limits and whether the defendant would have to disclose them. I advised that the limits would not be disclosed right away and that they may be disclosed during the discovery process. He also asked whether he would be receiving copies of all correspondence throughout the litigation. I advised that it is not typical for us to CC the client on all correspondence; he is welcome to call in for updates as things progress, but updates take time. He expressed understanding.

The matter appears to be ongoing, with communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Plano Surgical Hospital Funding LLC concerning the motor vehicle accident case. On October 5, 2023, Maggie Gonzalez of Plano Surgical Hospital Funding LLC emailed to note that Muhammad Alif’s case is still open and to request a status update. In that message, she itemized open balances: Cutting Edge Orthopedic totaling $25,763.75, and Plano Surgical Hospital – Legent totaling $2,553.70. The message was sent from Plano Surgical Hospital Funding LLC, Office: (772) 546-9591, and included a confidentiality notice typical of such correspondence.

Earlier the same day, October 6, 2023, at 10:33 a.m., Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Maggie, requesting the Date of Incident related to this accounting. Sarena provided her contact details: Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line (502) 357-9971; office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address).

Later on October 6, 2023, at approximately 1:59 p.m., Maggie Gonzalez responded with the Date of Incident on file as November 8, 2022 (11/08/2022). The message also carried Plano Surgical Hospital Funding LLC’s confidentiality notice.

At 2:12 p.m. on October 6, 2023, Sarena Tuttle sent another email stating that the claim is in litigation and that the Written Discovery Phase has just been entered. She noted that it will be approximately 120 days before there is any substantial movement regarding the lien. She added that once the process moves toward mediation scheduling, they will reach out to ensure they have all updated bills and ledgers. She invited the recipients to contact them directly if they have questions for further discussion. Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-11-08-2022. Client: Muhammad Alif.

On November 17, 2023, in the Muhammad Alif motor vehicle accident case, the Whaley Law Firm exchanged emails regarding discovery matters for the Muhammed Alif file. The initial message, sent at 1:09 PM by Aaron Whaley to Sarena Tuttle and copied to Bryce Koon and Muhammad Alif (with Muhammad Alif’s Filevine email address also included in the CC), carried the subject “Re: Muhammad Alif 11/08/22” and requested that a letter be sent regarding late discovery responses.

Earlier that same day, at approximately 1:07 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied. She indicated that on 09.29.2023 an email was found in the Defense Counsel Correspondence, and that the actual discovery requests are in the Pleadings Folder. Her message was accompanied by her signature block, which identified her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, including her contact details and noting a new email address.

At about 12:26 PM, Aaron Whaley followed up with a question: “When was discovery served on Wickliffe?”

Earlier still, around 11:40 AM, Sarena Tuttle wrote back to Aaron: “Hey AW, We have Mo’s Answers – Need Final Drafting. Served Def Wickliffe – No Response. Need to discuss Disc Req for Harbor House, if any.” This message also carried Sarena’s standard signature block and contact information.

Then, at about 10:43 AM, Aaron Whaley asked: “Have we filed our responses to interrogatories and RFPD? Do we have responses to our interrogatories? Have we confirmed our interrogatories were served if there has not been a response?” This message was followed by another signature block for Aaron Whaley and the Whaley Law Firm.

The thread culminates with the closing signature from Aaron Whaley, which repeats the firm’s name and address: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the contact number 502-583-4022.
